query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Noi eravamo al sommo de la scala, 2 dove secondamente si risega 3 lo monte che salendo altrui dismala.
query.error: **English:** 1 We were at the top of the staircase, 2 where one climbs a second time 3 the mountain that, as one ascends, relieves one's weariness.
query.result: 1 We wæron ða on ðære stægere hliðe, 2 ðær ðæt eft siððan onginneð 3 ðone munt stigan se ðe stigende geswinceð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Ivi così una cornice lega 5 dintorno il poggio, come la primaia; 6 se non che l’arco suo più tosto piega.
query.error: **English:** 4 There a cornice binds 5 around the hill, like the first; 6 except that its arc curves more quickly.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Ombra non lì è né segno che si paia: 8 parsi la ripa e parsi la via schietta 9 col livido color de la petraia.
query.error: **English:** 7 There is no shadow there, nor any sign that pairs with it: 8 the bank and the clear path appear 9 with the livid color of the stone.
query.result: 7 Sceadu næfre ne bið né sunne lixeð: 8 þær bið wonn weg and weder unhiure 9 and forstes frore and fyres blæst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 «Se qui per dimandar gente s’aspetta», 11 ragionava il poeta, «io temo forse 12 che troppo avrà d’indugio nostra eletta».
query.error: **English:** 10 "If one waits here to ask for people," 11 reasoned the poet, "I fear perhaps 12 that our choice will have too much delay."
query.result: 10 "Gif man her ondrædan sceal 11 folcgesteallan," ðuhte ðam frægnan, "ðonne ic ðæt mæne, 12 ðæt ðeos gesceaft hwilum sceal ondrædan."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Poi fisamente al sole li occhi porse; 14 fece del destro lato a muover centro, 15 e la sinistra parte di sé torse.
query.error: **English:** 13 Then he fixed his eyes intently on the sun; 14 he made the center move to his right side, 15 and turned the left part of himself away.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 «O dolce lume a cui fidanza i’ entro 17 per lo novo cammin, tu ne conduci», 18 dicea, «come condur si vuol quinc’ entro.
query.error: **English:** 16 "O sweet light, in whom I trust 17 for the new journey, you lead us," 18 he said, "as one must be led here within.
query.result: 16 "Eala ðu leohte leofran ðe ic on truwige 17 ðurh ðone niwan stige, ðu us læt 18 ðurh ðisne weg swa ðe her innan gebyreð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Tu scaldi il mondo, tu sovr’ esso luci; 20 s’altra ragione in contrario non ponta, 21 esser dien sempre li tuoi raggi duci».
query.error: **English:** 19 You warm the world, you shine upon it; 20 if no other reason opposes, 21 your rays should always be leaders.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Quanto di qua per un migliaio si conta, 23 tanto di là eravam noi già iti, 24 con poco tempo, per la voglia pronta;
query.error: **English:** 22 As far as one can count a thousand steps from here, 23 so far had we already gone on the other side, 24 in a short time, because of our eager desire;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 e verso noi volar furon sentiti, 26 non però visti, spiriti parlando 27 a la mensa d’amor cortesi inviti.
query.error: **English:** 25 and toward us were heard flying, 26 but not seen, spirits speaking 27 courteous invitations to the table of love.
query.result: 25 and ongean us wæron fleogende gehyrde, 26 ac ðeah ne gesewene, gastas sprecende 27 to ðære lufe mæðle milde gecigde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 La prima voce che passò volando 29 ‘Vinum non habent’ altamente disse, 30 e dietro a noi l’andò reïterando.
query.error: **English:** 28 The first voice that passed by flying 29 said loudly, ‘They have no wine,’ 30 and behind us it went, repeating it.
query.result: 28 Se forma ðe ðære stemne ðe ðær ærest fleag 29 ‘Vinum non habent’ hlude clypode, 30 and eft æfter us ða word sprecende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E prima che del tutto non si udisse 32 per allungarsi, un’altra ‘I’ sono Oreste’ 33 passò gridando, e anco non s’affisse.
query.error: **English:** 31 And before he had completely stopped shouting, 32 another one passed by, crying out, “I am Orestes,” 33 and he also did not stop.
query.result: 31 And ær ðe he ealunga ne geswice 32 for ðam hlýdan, ða ðurh ða menigu 33 oðer ðurh ða preatas ðus clypode,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 «Oh!», diss’ io, «padre, che voci son queste?». 35 E com’ io domandai, ecco la terza 36 dicendo: ‘Amate da cui male aveste’.
query.error: **English:** 34 "Oh!" said I, "father, what voices are these?" 35 And as I asked, behold, the third 36 saying: 'Loved by him from whom you had evil'.
query.result: 34 "Eala," cwæð ic, "fæder, hwæt ða stefna sind?" 35 And swa ic ða frignode, ða ða ðridde cwæð: 36 "Leofad ðurh ðone ðe ðe lað wæs."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 E ’l buon maestro: «Questo cinghio sferza 38 la colpa de la invidia, e però sono 39 tratte d’amor le corde de la ferza.
query.error: **English:** 37 And the good master: "This lash torments 38 the sin of envy, and therefore are 39 drawn from love the cords of the whip.
query.result: 37 And se goda lareow: "Þeos swipa swingð 38 ðære niðascylde, and forðæm sind 39 fram lufe getealde ða strengas ðære swipan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Lo fren vuol esser del contrario suono; 41 credo che l’udirai, per mio avviso, 42 prima che giunghi al passo del perdono.
query.error: **English:** 40 The rein must be of the opposite sound; 41 I think you will hear it, in my opinion, 42 before you reach the pass of forgiveness.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Ma ficca li occhi per l’aere ben fiso, 44 e vedrai gente innanzi a noi sedersi, 45 e ciascun è lungo la grotta assiso».
query.error: **English:** 43 But fix your eyes intently through the air, 44 and you will see people sitting in front of us, 45 and each one is seated along the cave.
query.result: 43 Ac fæst ðine eagan ðurh ðone lyft wel fæste, 44 and ðu gesyhst folc beforan us sittan, 45 and ælc bið be ðære græfðe geseten.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Allora più che prima li occhi apersi; 47 guarda’mi innanzi, e vidi ombre con manti 48 al color de la pietra non diversi.
query.error: **English:** 46 Then more than before I opened my eyes; 47 I looked ahead and saw shades with cloaks 48 no different in color from the stone.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 E poi che fummo un poco più avanti, 50 udia gridar: ‘Maria, òra per noi’: 51 gridar ‘Michele’ e ‘Pietro’ e ‘Tutti santi’.
query.error: **English:** 49 And after we had gone a little further, 50 I heard a voice crying: ‘Mary, pray for us’: 51 crying ‘Michael’ and ‘Peter’ and ‘All saints’.
query.result: 49 And ða we wæron lyt ðanon forð, 50 ða ic gehyrde gnornian: ‘Maria, gebidde for us’: 51 gnornian ‘Michael’ and ‘Petrus’ and ‘Ealle ða halgan’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Non credo che per terra vada ancoi 53 omo sì duro, che non fosse punto 54 per compassion di quel ch’i’ vidi poi;
query.error: **English:** 52 I do not believe that on earth there goes today 53 a man so hard that he would not have been pricked 54 with pity for what I saw then;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 ché, quando fui sì presso di lor giunto, 56 che li atti loro a me venivan certi, 57 per li occhi fui di grave dolor munto.
query.error: **English:** 55 for when I was so near to them that their actions 56 became clear to me, 57 I wept for grief.
query.result: 55 ða ic wæs swa neah ðæt ic ðara manna weorc 56 geseah and gehyrde, ða weard ic mid ðam earmre folce 57 for ðære miclan earmðe hreowig-mod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Di vil ciliccio mi parean coperti, 59 e l’un sofferia l’altro con la spalla, 60 e tutti da la ripa eran sofferti.
query.error: **English:** 58 They seemed to me to be covered with vile haircloth, 59 and one supported the other with his shoulder, 60 and all were supported by the bank.
query.result: 58 Hi wæron ðæs wælsliðan wædum bewrigen, 59 and ðær æghwylc oðerne mid ðære eaxle underpróp, 60 and ealle ða ða ofer ða ofre wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Così li ciechi a cui la roba falla, 62 stanno a’ perdoni a chieder lor bisogna, 63 e l’uno il capo sopra l’altro avvalla,
query.error: **English:** 61 Thus the blind, to whom the daylight fails, 62 stand at the pardons to beg for their needs, 63 and one upon the other's head he falls,
query.result: 61 Swa ða blindan ðe ðam dæge lyht losian, 62 standað æt ðam gebedhusum ða earfeðan biddan, 63 and oðer his heafod ofer ðæs oðres hrycg hyld,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 perché ’n altrui pietà tosto si pogna, 65 non pur per lo sonar de le parole, 66 ma per la vista che non meno agogna.
query.error: **English:** 64 so that pity may quickly be aroused in others, 65 not only by the sound of the words, 66 but by the sight which no less appeals.
query.result: 64 ðæt ðæt hrade ðurh oðerra manna mildheortnesse ðæt ðearf sylle, 65 na ðurh ðara worda hlysa ana, 66 ac ðurh ða gesyhðe ðe na ðæs læs wilnað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 E come a li orbi non approda il sole, 68 così a l’ombre quivi, ond’ io parlo ora, 69 luce del ciel di sé largir non vole;
query.error: **English:** 67 And as the sun does not help the blind, 68 so in the shadows there, of which I now speak, 69 the light of heaven does not want to give of itself;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 ché a tutti un fil di ferro i cigli fóra 71 e cusce sì, come a sparvier selvaggio 72 si fa però che queto non dimora.
query.error: **English:** 70 for a thread of iron would pierce the eyelids of all 71 and thighs too, as is done to a wild hawk 72 so that it does not remain still.
query.result: 70 forðæm ðe ðær isernbend eagena gehwylces 71 and ðara sceoncena swilce wilde hafoce, 72 ðy læs ðe he wunige ofer ðam wicum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 A me pareva, andando, fare oltraggio, 74 veggendo altrui, non essendo veduto: 75 per ch’io mi volsi al mio consiglio saggio.
query.error: **English:** 73 To me it seemed, as I went on, to be an outrage, 74 seeing others, not being seen: 75 therefore I turned to my wise counsel.
query.result: 73 Me ðuhte ða ða ic forth gewat, ðæt wære unriht, 74 ðæt ic oðre gesawe, and ic gesewen nære: 75 forðæm ic me wende to minum wisan ræde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Ben sapev’ ei che volea dir lo muto; 77 e però non attese mia dimanda, 78 ma disse: «Parla, e sie breve e arguto».
query.error: **English:** 76 He knew well what the mute man wanted to say; 77 and therefore he did not wait for my question, 78 but said: "Speak, and be brief and to the point."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Virgilio mi venìa da quella banda 80 de la cornice onde cader si puote, 81 perché da nulla sponda s’inghirlanda;
query.error: **English:** 79 Virgil was coming toward me from that side 80 of the cornice from which one can fall, 81 because it is not encircled by any bank;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 da l’altra parte m’eran le divote 83 ombre, che per l’orribile costura 84 premevan sì, che bagnavan le gote.
query.error: **English:** 82 on the other side were the devout 83 shades, who pressed so closely together because of the horrible torture 84 that their cheeks were bathed in tears.
query.result: 82 on ðære oðre healfe wæron ða halgan 83 gesceaftas, ða ðurh ða egeslican nacode 84 ðrungon swa ðætte hiora wlite bewæter wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Volsimi a loro e: «O gente sicura», 86 incominciai, «di veder l’alto lume 87 che ’l disio vostro solo ha in sua cura,
query.error: **English:** 85 I turned to them and said, "O people secure," 86 I began, "of seeing the high light 87 that your desire alone holds in its care,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 se tosto grazia resolva le schiume 89 di vostra coscïenza sì che chiaro 90 per essa scenda de la mente il fiume,
query.error: **English:** 88 if grace soon dissolves the foam 89 of your conscience so that clearly 90 through it the river of the mind descends,
query.result: 88 gif ðin milts ða sceal ða scamol toweorpan 89 ðinre gewiðrisne swa ðæt ðurh ða ðone stream ðæs modes cume, 90 sege me, forðæm ðe hit me bið wynsum and leof,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 ditemi, ché mi fia grazioso e caro, 92 s’anima è qui tra voi che sia latina; 93 e forse lei sarà buon s’i’ l’apparo».
query.error: **English:** 91 Tell me, for it will be gracious and dear to me, 92 if there is a soul here among you who is Latin; 93 and perhaps it will be good for me if I learn it.
query.result: 91 Secgað me, for ðam me bið georn and leof, 92 gif ænig mon is her on ðissum herige 93 and he Læden gecnawe; ðæt bið me selest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 «O frate mio, ciascuna è cittadina 95 d’una vera città; ma tu vuo’ dire 96 che vivesse in Italia peregrina».
query.error: **English:** 94 "O my brother, each one is a citizen 95 of a true city; but you want to say 96 that she lived in Italy as a pilgrim."
query.result: 94 "Eala, broðor min, ælc is burhsittende 95 soðfæstre ceastre; ac ðu woldest secgan 96 ðæt heo on Italia wæs elþeodigu."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Questo mi parve per risposta udire 98 più innanzi alquanto che là dov’ io stava, 99 ond’ io mi feci ancor più là sentire.
query.error: **English:** 97 This seemed to me to hear in answer 98 a little further on from where I stood, 99 whence I made myself heard even more.
query.result: 97 ðis ðuhte me ðæt ic ðær andsware 98 gehørde lyt ðanon ðær ic ða stôd, 99 ðanon ic me sylfne ða swiðor gehyrde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Tra l’altre vidi un’ombra ch’aspettava 101 in vista; e se volesse alcun dir ‘Come?’, 102 lo mento a guisa d’orbo in sù levava.
query.error: **English:** 100 Among the others I saw a shade who waited 101 in sight; and if anyone wished to say, “How?”, 102 he raised his chin upward like a blind man.
query.result: 100 Betwux ðam ic geseah ænne sceadu ðe ðær abide, 101 on gesyhðe; and gif ænig wiste acsian “Hu?”, 102 ða he ðone muð up ofer ða moldan arærde,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 «Spirto», diss’ io, «che per salir ti dome, 104 se tu se’ quelli che mi rispondesti, 105 fammiti conto o per luogo o per nome».
query.error: **English:** 103 "Spirit," I said, "who are condemned to climb, 104 if you are the one who answered me, 105 tell me about yourself, either by place or by name."
query.result: 103 "Gast," cwæð ic, "ðe ðurh stige stihst, 104 gif ðu se ðe ðe me ær andwyrde, 105 sæge me be ðe selfum, oððe be stowe oððe be naman."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 «Io fui sanese», rispuose, «e con questi 107 altri rimendo qui la vita ria, 108 lagrimando a colui che sé ne presti.
query.error: **English:** 106 "I was a man of Siena," he replied, "and with these 107 others I am sent back here to this wretched life, 108 weeping to Him who grants it to us.
query.result: 106 "Ic wæs Sanesisc," he andswarode, "and mid ðissum 107 oðrum ic wunode ðær on ðære wælhreowan life, 108 wepende to ðam ðe ða wununge us geaf."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Savia non fui, avvegna che Sapìa 110 fossi chiamata, e fui de li altrui danni 111 più lieta assai che di ventura mia.
query.error: **English:** 109 I was not wise, although Sapìa 110 I was called, and I was more joyful 111 of others' misfortunes than of my own good fortune.
query.result: 109 Ic næs na wis, ðeah ðe ic Sapige 110 wære gehaten, and wæs ðara ðinga ðe oðrum yfele wæron 111 bliðre micle ðonne minra agenra goda.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 E perché tu non creda ch’io t’inganni, 113 odi s’i’ fui, com’ io ti dico, folle, 114 già discendendo l’arco d’i miei anni.
query.error: **English:** 112 And so that you do not believe that I deceive you, 113 hear if I was, as I tell you, foolish, 114 already descending the arch of my years.
query.result: 112 And ðæt ðu ne wene ðæt ic ðe leogan wille, 113 gehyr ðu ðonne gif ic ðe secge soð, 114 ðæt ic ða wæs on ðara geara gang.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Eran li cittadin miei presso a Colle 116 in campo giunti co’ loro avversari, 117 e io pregava Iddio di quel ch’e’ volle.
query.error: **English:** 115 My townsmen were near Colle, 116 having joined battle with their adversaries, 117 and I prayed to God for what He willed.
query.result: 115 Wæron ða burgware mine neah Colle, 116 on felda gegaderode mid heora fyndum, 117 and ic bæd God ælmihtig ðæs ðe he wolde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Rotti fuor quivi e vòlti ne li amari 119 passi di fuga; e veggendo la caccia, 120 letizia presi a tutte altre dispari,
query.error: **English:** 118 Broken I was there, and turned to the bitter 119 steps of flight; and seeing the chase, 120 I took joy unlike all others,
query.result: 118 To-brocen wæs ic ðær and gewende to ðam bitran 119 staðoleasum; and ða ic ða huntunge geseah, 120 ða onfeng ic gefean ungelic oðrum,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 tanto ch’io volsi in sù l’ardita faccia, 122 gridando a Dio: “Omai più non ti temo!”, 123 come fé ’l merlo per poca bonaccia.
query.error: **English:** 121 so much that I turned my bold face upward, 122 crying to God: “Now I fear you no more!”, 123 as the blackbird does in a brief lull.
query.result: 121 swa ðæt ic up awende ða ofermode neb, 122 cleopiende to Gode: “Nu ðu me ne ondrætst!”, 123 swa ða merle doð ðurh lytle hwile.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Pace volli con Dio in su lo stremo 125 de la mia vita; e ancor non sarebbe 126 lo mio dover per penitenza scemo,
query.error: **English:** 124 I made peace with God at the end 125 of my life; and my duty would not yet be 126 diminished by penance,
query.result: 124 Ic gesibsumode mid Gode on ðam ende 125 mines lifes; and min geweorc nære giet 126 ðurh dædbote,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 se ciò non fosse, ch’a memoria m’ebbe 128 Pier Pettinaio in sue sante orazioni, 129 a cui di me per caritate increbbe.
query.error: **English:** 127 if it were not that Pier Pettinaio remembered me 128 in his holy prayers, 129 for whom I was a source of sorrow out of charity.
query.result: 127 gif hit nære ðæt Petrus Pettinaio mîn gemunde 128 on his halgum gebedum, 129 ðam ic wæs for ðære lufan sarig.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Ma tu chi se’, che nostre condizioni 131 vai dimandando, e porti li occhi sciolti, 132 sì com’ io credo, e spirando ragioni?».
query.error: **English:** 130 But who are you, who go asking about our conditions, 131 and wear your eyes unbound, 132 as I believe, and speak while breathing?”.
query.result: 130 Ac ðu ðe eart, ðe ure gecyððu 131 geaxiao, and ðine eagan sind alysede, 132 swa swa ic gelyfe, and ðu sprecende lybbende?”.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 «Li occhi», diss’ io, «mi fieno ancor qui tolti, 134 ma picciol tempo, ché poca è l’offesa 135 fatta per esser con invidia vòlti.
query.error: **English:** 133 "My eyes," I said, "will still be taken from me here, 134 but for a short time, because the offense 135 committed by turning them with envy is small.
query.result: 133 "Þa eagan," cwæð ic, "me beoð her ða gyt genumene, 134 ac lyt swig, forðæm ðe lyt is seo yfelnes 135 gedon ðurh ðæt ðe hi wæron mid andan gewende."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Troppa è più la paura ond’ è sospesa 137 l’anima mia del tormento di sotto, 138 che già lo ’ncarco di là giù mi pesa».
query.error: **English:** 136 Too great is the fear with which my soul is suspended 137 from the torment below, 138 that already the burden of it weighs upon me from down there.
query.result: 136 To micel ys se ege ðe min mod hylt 137 ðæs wites ðe ðær wunigeð on ðam wyrrestan, 138 ðæt ðæs ðær wunigeð ðæs hreoh mæg wægan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Ed ella a me: «Chi t’ha dunque condotto 140 qua sù tra noi, se giù ritornar credi?». 141 E io: «Costui ch’è meco e non fa motto.
query.error: **English:** 139 And she to me: "Who has led you here 140 up here among us, if you think to return below?". 141 And I: "This one who is with me and does not speak.
query.result: 139 And heo to me: "Hwa ðe ðonne lædde 140 her upp betwux us, gif ðu eft wenst?". 141 And ic: "Þes ðe is mid me and ne spriced noht.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 E vivo sono; e però mi richiedi, 143 spirito eletto, se tu vuo’ ch’i’ mova 144 di là per te ancor li mortai piedi».
query.error: **English:** 142 And I am alive; and therefore you ask me, 143 chosen spirit, if you want me to move 144 my mortal feet for you again on the other side».
query.result: 142 And ic lybbe; and forðæm ðu me frigne, 143 gast god, gif ðu wylle ðæt ic eftsið 144 ðurh ðe ða deadan fotas læde».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 «Oh, questa è a udir sì cosa nuova», 146 rispuose, «che gran segno è che Dio t’ami; 147 però col priego tuo talor mi giova.
query.error: **English:** 145 "Oh, this is such a new thing to hear," 146 he replied, "that it is a great sign that God loves you; 147 therefore I sometimes help you with your prayers.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
148 E cheggioti, per quel che tu più brami, 149 se mai calchi la terra di Toscana, 150 che a’ miei propinqui tu ben mi rinfami.
query.error: **English:** 148 And I ask you, by that which you most desire, 149 if ever you tread the land of Tuscany, 150 that you speak well of me to my kindred.
query.result: 148 And ic bidde ðe, ðurh ðæt ðe ðu mast lufige, 149 gif ðu æfre becymst to ðære Tuscane leode, 150 ðæt ðu mine mægðe wel mine word secge.

query.prompt:
